item.title: One Bad Afternoon. Twenty-Three Years of Consequences.
item.description:
Birmingham International Airport, 1984.

A small elevated shuttle is running a 600-metre track at 42 km/h, carrying passengers between the terminal and the railway station. No wheels touching rails. No combustion. A linear induction motor — a horizontal electromagnetic field dragging a reaction plate through space — doing what wheels and pistons used to do.

The world’s first commercial maglev people mover. Running. Doing its job.

The man most responsible for the engineering principles underneath it wasn’t there. He was eight years into the institutional exile that had started with one bad afternoon in 1974.

item.title: The Planet Is a Resonator. Stop Making It Weird.
item.description: The Earth has a resonant frequency. It’s 7.83 Hz. This was predicted by a German physicist named Winfried Otto Schumann in 1952. He and his collaborator H.L. König published the first measurements in 1954. More comprehensive experimental confirmation followed from Balser and Wagner between 1960 and 1963. It has been measured continuously at monitoring stations around the world ever since. It is one of the most thoroughly documented electromagnetic phenomena in geophysics.

item.title: Chapman Got Conferences. Birkeland Got a Banknote.
item.description: Norway put Kristian Birkeland on their 200 krone note in 1994. On the front: his face, the aurora borealis behind him, his terrella experiment — a miniature magnetized Earth he’d built in a vacuum chamber to demonstrate how solar electrons create auroral light. On the back: a map of the Arctic polar region, with a ring drawn around the magnetic dip pole, marking exactly where the currents he’d predicted flow into the ionosphere.

item.title: The Physics Nobel Called It Fraud. The Astrophysicist Found What He Said He'd Find.
item.description:
In February 2021, Randell Mills demonstrated a plasma device in Washington DC that he claimed was generating 100,000 watts of continuous steam power. He called a press release. He showed the device. He made the claim.

Then the physics community continued not caring.

This is, roughly, the shape of the Randell Mills story for the last thirty-four years. Something happens. A number gets announced. Credentialed observers note something unusual. Then: silence, sarcasm, the occasional Nobel laureate dropping the word “fraud,” and everything continuing exactly as before.

item.title: The Word Died in 1989. The Experiment Didn't.
item.description:
The press conference was the crime. Not the science - the press conference.

March 23, 1989. Martin Fleischmann and Stanley Pons stand in front of cameras at the University of Utah and announce they’ve achieved nuclear fusion at room temperature. In a glass jar. With palladium electrodes and heavy water. The physics establishment’s reaction landed somewhere between “excuse me?” and “how dare you.”

Nobody cracks down on a failed experiment. What they cracked down on was the venue. You don’t announce nuclear fusion without peer review. You don’t do it at a press conference. You don’t do it before independent replication is in. These were genuine violations of genuine norms and the physics community had a real point.

item.title: Feynman Said Sorry. Fusion Physics Didn't Get the Memo.
item.description:
Here is a thing that actually happened: Richard Feynman — the Feynman, the bongo-playing, safe-cracking, Nobel Prize-winning conscience of 20th century physics — wrote an apology letter in 1986 to a researcher named Kenneth Shoulders.

The subject: stable electron clusters containing ten billion electrons.

Feynman’s initial position: impossible. Coulomb repulsion would tear them apart instantly.

Feynman’s revised position, after seeing Shoulders’ data: “is indeed possible.”

That letter should have changed everything. You already know it didn’t. But do you know why?

item.title: Seventy Thousand Degrees in a Water Glass
item.description:
They discovered it with sonar equipment in 1934. They said they had more important matters. They did.

There is a bubble of air at the center of a glass flask. Someone turns on a speaker. It expands — swells to fifty microns, about half the width of a human hair. Then the acoustic wave flips. The pressure outside reverses. The atmosphere decides it’s done being polite.

What happens next takes less than a nanosecond.

item.title: String Theory: Physics' Forty-Year Con Job
item.description:
They sold us eleven dimensions and delivered zero predictions. Welcome to the greatest intellectual pyramid scheme in physics history, where mathematical beauty became the excuse for scientific bankruptcy, and two generations of brilliant physicists got eaten alive by a framework that can’t be tested, can’t be falsified, and somehow — SOMEHOW — keeps getting funding.

Forty years. Forty years of conferences and textbooks and tenure committees selecting for string theory fluency. What did we get? Ten to the power of 500 possible universes. That’s not a Theory of Everything. That’s a confession that you have no fucking idea what’s happening, written in sufficiently exotic notation that you need a PhD to recognize the confession.

item.title: What Happens When You Look
item.description:
Quantum mechanics is the most accurate scientific theory in human history. The Dirac equation predicts the magnetic moment of the electron to 12 decimal places. The Standard Model has been confirmed to parts per trillion. No theory has been more precisely validated by experiment.

None of this tells you what happens when you look.

The wavefunction collapse problem – what occurs when a quantum system is measured – has been unresolved since Heisenberg in 1927. Not unresolved as in “partially understood, more work needed.” Unresolved as in: physicists actively disagree about whether anything happens at all, whether the word “happens” is even applicable, and whether asking the question constitutes legitimate physics or the kind of philosophy they agreed to stop doing.
